text: on Thursday Israeli soldiers fired deep
into Gaza City hitting a warehouse used
by the United Nations there UN Secretary
Ban ki-moon strongly protested the
strike Israel claimed however that Hamas
militants had fired off mortars from
near the warehouse and then ran inside
it for safety the United Nations denied
that also on Thursday a top Hamas leader
was killed siats I am was the interior
minister and important because he
controls Hamas troops in nearly three
weeks of fighting no journalists have
been allowed to enter Gaza through
Israel but on Thursday New York Times
correspondent ethan bronner spent a day
with an Israeli unit in northwest Gaza
when the ground war began on a Saturday
night they took this area and the houses
are cleared out the lot of this
agricultural land where they found
rocket launchers in the houses they
found tons and booby traps and
mannequins all aimed at drawing Israeli
soldiers in and apparently ideally to
try to sort of grab them in order to
kidnap them and move them down into the
tunnels the Israelis seem to have been
aware of it and none have been taken as
far as we know so far so the unit that
we visited today has been there for
about 10 days there's been a fair amount
of activity around it there's been some
injuries in the last couple of days on
the some of the hills and the bluffs
that they were in the colonel talked
about the need to continue this but of
course would accept whatever the
political echelon has decided in terms
of a ceasefire his argument was that
Hamas needed to be taught a harsh lesson
that it's an organization that clearly
expected to be able to suck the Israeli
soldiers in and do damage to them at
least so it appears and it's the Israeli
claim that that's not what happened this
time
despite the continued shelling in Gaza
Israel's reviewing the terms of a
ceasefire discussed the Hamas leaders in
Egypt and so three weeks in they're
still fighting but the talking seems to
be getting more serious
